A lifelong stoic and introvert who's not big on asking questions, I regret not speaking up which had I done so may have had a positive effect on my marriage that sadly ended in divorce after 32 years, my career which was modest at best, my relationships with family and friends which tend to be one sided, and my overall quality of life.

I regret not helping my mom when she discovered she had cancer.

Marrying and having children when i did.  I didn't know enough about the world, love, other people, etc. (only minor things) at the time.  Whilst people obviously change, and there is a need work and change with them and the new relationships, i feel like it was a major decision that i didn't fully understand enough about to make a good one.  I know that sounds bad...!
Not fixing my body post-injury sooner. Could've had so many awesome memories and great experiences playing all around the world if I had.
Not honouring my self - allowing others needs to matter more than my own
I regret that i got involved in someone else's private matters

When I was in upper elementary school, my friend and I auditioned for the school pop group. Naively, I think we assumed that both of us would be selected, or neither of us would be. Only 3-4 students were chosen to represent the hundreds on the school roll. I should have been thrilled when my name was announced, but my friend missed out, and, such was her influence and control, I felt compelled to decline. The music teacher contacted my parents and all three spent days imploring me to reconsider. I stubbornly refused. On the night of the performance, I regretted not being up on stage - the group appeared to be having so much fun. But the greater regret, the part that has stayed with me all my life, has been knowing that I didn’t take the chance that came my way because I succumbed to pressure from a person who felt no joy over my achievement; only bitterness as a result of her own disappointment. I’ve always been grateful for the lesson, but the choice I made remains a deep regret.
Listening to someone say I cannot dance and then giving it up.
- Not completing my PMP certification.
Worrying too much about How I look and what others think of me that it hindered me from really living my full potential and doing and being what makes me most happy.
I regret many discussions with muy father, i was just a kid that needed to fight. Nowadays i would rather fight against many injustices of the world.
I wasn't "there" for my grandmother at the end of her life. I nursed petty grievances; I blew it.
I regret not having been a better, kinder, more patient parent.
Ever dieting. Once you start that cycle you are onto a losing journey forever.

regretList.regret: Travelling down the road of regret can be a dangerous practice if not conducted with objectivity. Because even as I look back on what I might consider a regret, was actually lots of situations largely outside my control. It’s only I’m in my thirties that I see the opportunities and finding the bravery to decide. Looking forward, I don’t want to regret choosing not to choose with intention.

My partner did not want to have children. I did, we split up, but came together again as I gave in. Now, 25 years later, I regret not having children.

Not going to Paris as an au pair, because I was (last minute) admitted to the school of my choice. I could have studied a year later, but I missed an important possibility to be in Paris for a year, learn French fluently and get some important life experiences. I was too responsible.
Not making relationship decisions easier, wasting time with struggling

Went back to an old PR agency to become MD and left a well-paid gig in a huge tech company. Boss wasn't upfront about revenue situation so I got fired. My six months was a back-breaking thankless nightmare. That was five years ago. Went into depression. Haven't recovered since.

I regret always perceiving myself as fat when in reality I was slim and beautiful. This has led to years of trying to lose weight. 
Now when I have gained too much weight, my body no longer responds to any attempts. I have now come terms with the way I look and live with peace in my mind.
That I have to go to work for making a living
Wish i did’t leave my country when i was young. Have lived in three different countries and feel homeless.

Biggest regret ever: leaving my one true love 25 years ago, because I was too young back then to have the courage to stay in a foreign country without an education or job and not skilled enough in the local language to obtain either within a reasonable time period. Went back to my home country and got a great education and an even more fantastic job, but have not been able to find the right match thus leading to trying out the concept: if you cannot get the one you love, try to love the one you can get (which is a poor choice!)

That I decided to marry a woman I have been struggling to live with for almost seven years now just to please my aging parents who thought it would do them an honour to see me married before their retirement age. It feels like my real wife is also married somewhere else as I had to push her away for the woman I live with now...total regret that one
I regret not listening to my instincts earlier because it would save me from severe depression due to an abusive relationship.

I regret that I did not know more about the time I grew up in while I was growing up in South Africa. Although I never mistreated any person of color, I never did anything to end Apartheid. However, I've been giving back for many years through the career I've chosen.

listened more and be more confident in myself.

I regret breaking off the contact to a friend I had a crush on ten years ago. At that time I thought I couldn’t handle the pain of a broken heart. Nowadays I regret my decisions because I’ve learned that crushes and heartaches go away and that friendships could last through those feelings.

Not spending more time with my grandmother, since I was studying in Germany and, everytime I flew back to Spain, I ended up spending more time with my friends and my girlfriend (at the time). I wished I had spent more quality time with her.

Standing up for myself more, setting clear boundaries for how to be treated regardless of how the other person reacts to the boundaries. Looking back  on the things I regret it’s always when I didn’t do the right thing, by me, family, friends, by people or the environment. Doing the next right thing is such a core value for me.

not being a better/present parent for my first son
